docs.lead_paragraph: The effort to slash tax rates and to cover the cost in savings from entitlement programs is seen by critics as futile.

headline.seo: House Republicans to Tackle Federal Budget
headline.main: House Republicans to Tackle Ambitious Budget
headline.print_headline: House Republicans to Tackle Ambitious Budget

docs.abstract: House Republicans will return from spring recess to face the difficult task of filling the gaping holes in the House-passed budget, including figuring out how to slash income tax rates without costing the government any money; they will also have to find nearly $3 trillion in savings from entitlement programs over the next decade.
docs.snippet: The effort to slash tax rates and to cover the cost in savings from entitlement programs is seen by critics as futile.

keywords.value: House Committee on Ways and Means
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act will either be fully paid for or will begin to address the Medicare problem — not both.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by contributing opinion writer Steven Rattner argues that the government's plan to pay for the Obama health care law with Medicare expense reductions and tax increases is deficient and deceptive, since it double-counts the savings and revenue increases towards both Medicare and the cost of the Obama plan.
docs.snippet: The Affordable Care Act will either be fully paid for or will begin to address the Medicare problem — not both.

headline.main: DealBook's Week in Review: Awash in Cash

docs.abstract: We examined Facebook's $1 billion deal for a mobile start-up, Microsoft's $1 billion deal for patents and a $2.15 billion "lawsuit waiting to happen." A look back on our reporting of the past week's highs and lows in finance.

headline.main: Is There a Republican Alternative to Obamacare?

docs.abstract: Some Republicans have indeed put forward some serious alternatives to President Obama’s plans for health care reform, though it is not clear if or how well they might work, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: Some Republicans have indeed put forward some serious alternatives to President Obama’s plans for health care reform, though it is not clear if or how well they might work, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: After the Republican-controlled New York Senate declined to consider a health insurance exchange, the governor issued an executive order to create it within the State Health Department.

headline.seo: Cuomo Orders Health Insurance Exchange in New York
headline.main: Cuomo Acts to Advance Health Law in New York
headline.print_headline: Cuomo Acts To Advance Health Law In New York

docs.abstract: New York Gov Andrew M Cuomo steps into national debate over health care reform, offering an enthusiastic endorsement of the law's benefits and issuing an executive order to establish a health insurance exchange in New York; order will create an online marketplace offering choice of competing health insurance plans, a measure the Republican majority in the State Senate has refused to consider.
docs.snippet: After the Republican-controlled New York Senate declined to consider a health insurance exchange, the governor issued an executive order to create it within the State Health Department.

docs.lead_paragraph: So-called specialty drugs for diseases like rheumatoid arthritis have a narrow use and high costs, leaving the most vulnerable patients with huge bills.

headline.seo: States Seek to Curb Exorbitant Drug Costs Incurred by Patients
headline.main: States Seek Curb on Patient Bills for Costly Drugs
headline.print_headline: States Seek Curb On Patient Bills For Costly Drugs

docs.abstract: Lawmakers in at least 20 states have introduced bills that would limit out-of-pocket payments by consumers for expensive drugs used to treat chronic diseases; bills aim to counter efforts by health plans to reduce the amount they pay for expensive medicines by making patients pay a percentage of the cost.
docs.snippet: So-called specialty drugs for diseases like rheumatoid arthritis have a narrow use and high costs, leaving the most vulnerable patients with huge bills.
